title: Fewer young people are working — here’s why that could be a good thing
text:
The idea of young adults working is getting old.

The teen labor force participation rate has been dropping for years, and will continue to decline in the coming decade, according to two different analyses released this week.

But forget the grumbles about slacker kids these days lacking a work ethic.

The two reports have one recurring theme: kids are spending less time at jobs, but they’re spending more time at school, building up skills and knowledge that may pay off in the long run.

“The shift toward higher school enrollment rates means that youth today are investing more in their human capital,” Brookings Institution researchers wrote. “To the extent that American youth are spending more time in school, they may be increasing their prospects for good labor market outcomes later in life.”

Between 2000 and 2018, the workforce participation rate for ages 16 to 19 fell from about one half of the population to one third, the think tank said. The participation rate for ages 20 to 24 dropped from almost 80% to about 71%, where it’s held steady since 2010, according to Brookings.

The plunge in fresh-faced workers will continue into 2028, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics projections. The labor force participation rate for the 16- to 24-year-old age group is projected to shrink 3.5% from 2018 to 2028, the agency said.

As a result, just over half of the young working population (51.7%) will be part of the workforce by 2028, it said. That’s 14% drop from the rate in 1998, when almost 66% of the 16- to 24-year old demographic had a job or was looking for one.

Another factor pushing employment down for young people is that they’re competing against older workers who are sticking around in the job market longer, in part because some can’t afford to stop working.

Experts have long seen fewer young adults jumping into the jobs markets. Other researchers have said even with decades-low unemployment rates, high school graduates looking for a job have worse odds than their counterparts from 2000. One reason is that high school now gears them for college education, rather than immediate entry into the jobs market, they say.

“Labor force participation for youth is not an unalloyed good, in that there is generally a trade-off between work and schooling,” the Brookings Institution report said.

Education has its trade-offs too, now more than ever.

Americans currently have approximately $1.5 trillion in student loan debt hanging over their heads. Loans finance college studies, but repayments can be suffocating for many and foreclose plans for new houses, new kids and fledgling careers.

The Brookings study notes the time spent on education instead of work can have a good payoff. There’s a caveat though.

“This of course requires that the time spent on education be used in valuable ways, with students picking good post-secondary programs and schools improving skills and knowledge,” researchers wrote.
description: Youth employment rates are expected to decline through the next 10 years, experts say.
